caption:
This photograph depicts a flooded mobile home sales lot. The scene includes multiple mobile homes, primarily in colors of white with yellow and grey trims, arranged in distinct rows. The area is extensively waterlogged, with large puddles reflecting the mobile homes, suggesting recent heavy rainfall or flooding.

In the foreground, the terrain is visibly saturated with water, parts appearing like shallow pools, and patches of grass partially submerged. To the right, there is a prominent sign with bold lettering that reads "Louisiana Mobile Home Brokers SALES" complemented by the business phone numbers. The sky above is overcast, contributing to a gloomy atmosphere.

The mobile homes are unoccupied and there are no visible human activities, emphasizing the impact of flooding on the area. The background shows a fence and some low-rise structures, possibly part of the ongoing mobile home lot setup or neighboring buildings. Overall, the image conveys a sense of interruption and the tranquility of the area due to the water-induced disruption.
title: In the spring of 1973, the Mississippi River reached its highest level in more than 150 years. Unprecedented flooding occurred throughout the river basin. Particularly affected were the marsh area below New Orleans, and the entire Atchafalaya River basin flooded Mobile homes on Highway 90 on the north side of Houma.
